result.markdown: --- title: "Part 5: APA Write-Up" subtitle: "Lab 1: Descriptive Statistics" format: html filters: - webr webr: packages: ['readr', 'dplyr'] show-startup-message: false --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Watch the Demo Follow along with the slides below. ```{=html} ``` ::: {.callout-tip} ## Tip Click inside the slide area first, then use arrow keys to navigate. ::: --- ## Try It Yourself ::: {.callout-tip} ## How to Practice 1. **Generate your summary statistics** 2. **Use the template** to write your paragraph 3. **Copy to your RStudio exercise** for submission ::: ### Generate Your Statistics Run this to get all the numbers you need: ```{webr-r} library(readr) library(dplyr) # Load and prepare data data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv" data <- read_csv(data_url, show_col_types = FALSE) # Reverse-score items data$rev_G1 <- 6 - data$G1 data$rev_G3 <- 6 - data$G3 data$rev_G5 <- 6 - data$G5 data$rev_G6 <- 6 - data$G6 # Create subscales data$consistency <- data$rev_G1 + data$rev_G3 + data$rev_G5 + data$rev_G6 data$perseverance <- data$G2 + data$G4 + data$G7 + data$G8 data$Study_Year <- factor(data$Study_Year) # Overall statistics cat("=== OVERALL ===\n") cat("Consistency of Interest:\n") cat("M =", round(mean(data$consistency), 2), "\n") cat("SD =", round(sd(data$consistency), 2), "\n\n") cat("Perseverance of Effort:\n") cat("M =", round(mean(data$perseverance), 2), "\n") cat("SD =", round(sd(data$perseverance), 2), "\n") cat("N =", length(data$consistency), "\n\n") # By Study Year cat("=== BY STUDY YEAR ===\n") summary_stats <- data |> group_by(Study_Year) |> summarise( M_consistency = round(mean(consistency), 2), SD_consistency = round(sd(consistency), 2), M_perseverance = round(mean(perseverance), 2), SD_perseverance = round(sd(perseverance), 2), n = n(), .groups = "drop" ) print(summary_stats) ``` ### Create a Formatted Table ```{webr-r} library(readr) library(dplyr) data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv" data <- read_csv(data_url, show_col_types = FALSE) data$rev_G1 <- 6 - data$G1 data$rev_G3 <- 6 - data$G3 data$rev_G5 <- 6 - data$G5 data$rev_G6 <- 6 - data$G6 data$consistency <- data$rev_G1 + data$rev_G3 + data$rev_G5 + data$rev_G6 data$perseverance <- data$G2 + data$G4 + data$G7 + data$G8 data$Study_Year <- factor(data$Study_Year) summary_stats <- data |> group_by(Study_Year) |> summarise( M_consistency = round(mean(consistency), 2), SD_consistency = round(sd(consistency), 2), M_perseverance = round(mean(perseverance), 2), SD_perseverance = round(sd(perseverance), 2), n = n(), .groups = "drop" ) knitr::kable(summary_stats, caption = "Table 1. Descriptive Statistics for Grit Subscales by Study Year", col.names = c("Study Year", "M (Consistency)", "SD (Consistency)", "M (Perseverance)", "SD (Perseverance)", "n")) ``` --- ## APA Write-Up Template Use this template for your results paragraph. Fill in the blanks with your statistics: ::: {.callout-note} ## Template Participants reported [describe level] levels of Consistency of Interest overall (*M* = ___, *SD* = ___) and Perseverance of Effort (*M* = ___, *SD* = ___). First-year students showed [description] Consistency of Interest scores (*M* = ___, *SD* = ___, *n* = ___) compared to second-year students (*M* = ___, *SD* = ___, *n* = ___). For Perseverance of Effort, first-year students (*M* = ___, *SD* = ___) [similar/different] compared to second-year students (*M* = ___, *SD* = ___). These descriptive patterns suggest [your interpretation]. ::: ### Your Write-Up Write your paragraph here (or in your RStudio exercise): ::: {.callout-warning} ## Your Turn Look at your summary statistics above and fill in the template. Think about: - Which subscale shows larger differences between study years? - Are first-year or second-year students higher on Consistency of Interest? - What might explain differences in Perseverance of Effort? ::: --- ## Self-Assessment Check your understanding before finishing. ::: {.webex-check .webex-box} **1. In APA style, M stands for:** **2. How many decimal places should you use for M and SD?** **3. True or False: You only need to report means, not standard deviations.** **4. Which is correct APA format?** **5. A good results paragraph includes M, SD, and (sample size).** ::: --- ## Lab 1 Complete! Congratulations! You've learned: | Part | Skills | |------|--------| | 1 | R basics, downloading notebook | | 2 | Loading data, inspecting structure | | 3 | Reverse scoring Grit Scale items | | 4 | Calculating subscales, grouped descriptives, boxplots | | 5 | APA-style reporting | --- ## What's Next? ::: {.callout-tip} ## Coming Up in Lab 2 - **Independent samples t-test** - comparing two groups - **Paired samples t-test** - comparing pre vs post - **Effect sizes** - Cohen's d - **APA reporting** for inferential statistics ::: --- ## Extra Practice Want more practice? Try the follow-on exercise with a different dataset: ::: {.callout-important} ## Follow-On Exercise The follow-on exercise is a **`.qmd` notebook file** that you download and run in **RStudio Server** on your own time. It uses a different dataset (Wellbeing Study) to give you extra practice applying the same skills you learned in Lab 1. **To use it:** 1. Download the `.qmd` file below 2. Upload it to your RStudio Server workspace (same way you did with the main exercise) 3. Work through it independently to reinforce your learning ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: --- ## Navigation ::: {.d-flex .justify-content-between} [‚Üê Back to Part 4](part4.qmd){.btn .btn-secondary} [Back to Lab 1 Overview](index.qmd){.btn .btn-primary} :::
